The Chiefs of Staff reported the principal events of theprevious eight days.Bomber Command had carried out two major attacks, againstFrankfurt on the 20th December (with a diversionary attack onMannheim), and against Berlin on the 23rd December.2,100 tons of bombs had been dropped on " Crossbow " targetsby United Kingdom and United States Air Forces, with a goodmeasure of success.The United States Air Force had carried out raids againstBremen, Osnabruck and Munster.Coastal Command had made several attacks on blockade-runnersin the Bay of Biscay.Enemy losses for the week, including claims by the UnitedStates Air Force, amounted to 102 destroyed, 40 probably destroyed and 37 damaged. Our losses had been 58 bombers, 32 fighters and7 Coastal Command aircraft. The United States Air Force had lost 48 bombers.In the Mediterranean the Allied air forces had carried outnearly 7,000 sorties, against about 500 enemy sorties. We had lost56 aircraft.Shipping- losses for the week by enemy action, includingbelated reports, amounted to 32,265 tons. Total losses for Decemberso far amounted to 138,624 tons. Five German submarines had been sunk during December.Details were given of the sinking of the Scharnhorst on the26th December.The War Cabinet-Requested the First Lord of the Admiralty to convey theircongratulations to the Commander-in-Chief, Home Fleet,on this successful action.Two German blockade-runners had been sighted; one hadevaded our forces, but the second had been sunk by Coastal command aircraft. The German destroyers escorting the latter vessel hadbeen attacked by our cruisers that afternoon. The action was still proceeding.In the Eighth Army sector our forces had advanced 2 miles ona 5-mile front during the previous week. After street-to-streetfighting, we occupied two-thirds of Ortona. In the United Statessector some progress had also been made.On the previous day United States forces had landed without loss on both sides of Cape Gloucester in New Britain.In the Vitebsk sector the Russian advance continued and wasclosing in on the city. The railway from Vitebsk to Pologsk hadbeen cut. In the Kieff sector the Russians had launched a counter-offensive and claimed to have advanced some 25 miles on a 50-milefront. In general, the week had been a very satisfactory one for theRussians.The War Cabinet-Took note of these statements.Impending 2. Reference was made to statements published in AmericaOperations that over 70 per cent, of the forces engaged in the invasion ofagainst Western Europe would be American. The question was raised whether someEurope. further statement ought not to be made, to put the matter in itsProportion of proper perspective.British and The vice-Chief of the Imperial General Staff said that heUnited States would like time to consider this question, but suggested that anyForces. publication of the percentages of British and United States forces to be engaged in this operation would convey information to theenemy. Any further statement ought, therefore, to be in very general terms. The suggestion was also made that it might be desirable thatany further statement should be issued by the United states authorities and not from this country.The War Cabinet-Invited the Chiefs of Staff to report whether, from themilitary point of view, there was any objection to afurther statement being made as to the proportion ofBritish and United States forces to be engaged in theforthcoming operations against the Continent of Europe;and, if it were decided to make a further statement, what form it should take.Ban.Loss of ships in Harbour.(previous reference:W.M.(43)169thConclusions,Minute 1.)Foreign Affairs.Boumania,Yugoslavia.(previous reference:W.M. The War Cabinet were given certain information regardingthe loss of ships in Bari Harbour early in December as a result of enemy air action. A record of the discussion is contained in theSecretary's Standard File of War Cabinet Conclusions.4. The Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs gave the WarCabinet the latest information about developments in thesecountries. This is recorded in the Secretary's Standard File of WarCabinet Conclusions.5. The Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs said that ithad been suggested to him that it was important that every effort should be made to avoid bombing Florence.The Secretary of State for Air and the Chief of the Air Staffgave an assurance that full consideration had been, and was being,given by the authorities concerned to the avoidance of damage tohistoric and artistic buildings in Italy. Moreover, he knew thatthe Air Officer Commanding-in-Chief in the Mediterranean would do all in his power to attain the necessary military objectiveswithout bombing this city.The War Cabinet-Took note of these statements.Offices of the War Cabinet, S. W. 1,28th December, 1943.
